addressleaf.section: A Monsieur Monsieur de Sidney chevalier et Governeur de la Ville de Vlissingnes

page.lettertext:
fol.171r
S
r
Tho Bodley to S
r
Robert Sydney
There was nothing in my letter, but yo
r
L
ordship
might see, nor I never have any, but yo
w
may open very freely; albeit I am assured
it was not w
t
yo
r
will. W
t
muche a doe
I have overintreated this
Councel,
for a couple
of companies to be sent to
Ostend.
But they
must be Dutche, and they must be returned
when
e rest of their forces shall goe into the filde.
And this they hav e done, to satisfie her
Ma
tie
for otherwise they knowe,
at those alarmes, are
devised by
e Councell: and if his care be not
e
greater, to governe to their liking, he will pur-
hase to himself a great deale of trouble.
To that w
ch
Airnsma
proposed to yo
r
L
ordship
I was
never made privie, nor I knowe not as yet,
by whome he was authorised, or w
at
it was
that he delivered. But I thinke he was sette
a worke by those of
Zeland.
There is no-
thing w
t
with
us, that is ether newes, or like to
newes, but
S
r
Thomas Baskerville
, can discourse
it all at large. I would be glad to heare
from yo
r
L
ordship
of
Cap
t
Wraies
imploiement, and
of yo
r
good proceeding in that enterprise,
and so for this present I comend yo
r
endevo
rs
to Gods good direction. Fr
o
e Hage.
23 Marche. 1590
Yo
r
Lordships at co
m
andem
t
Tho. Bodley
